oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Samuel Frazier House (NR)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story, three bay house built of rough quarried marble ca. 1795; its "Penn Plan" design of three rooms is unusual in the county; one of the county's oldest houses
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: HOUSES AND BARNS IN BLOUNT COUNTY
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries, Digital Initiatives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Friends Church (NR)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Current Use: Since 1947, St. Andrew's Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- Colonial Revival style, brick with tile roof.
Historical -- Quaker meeting house, 1871-1936; Friends' impact on religion and education in Maryville and Blount County.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: MARYVILLE
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries, Digital Initiatives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jim Hatcher Barn
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: Cades Cove, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural and agricultural history -- double pen log barn with saddle and V notches; built about 1930 by Jim Hatcher, a later owner of the Elijah Oliver property
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: CADES COVE HISTORIC DISTRICT; (NR as Cades Cove Historic District)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries, Digital Initiatives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Charles M. Hall School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Address: 229 E. Watt St., Alcoa, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- one story brick school with hip and gable roof, built in 1926
Historical -- originally a segregated school for "colored"; later integrated and called Alcoa Middle School; ceased to be a school in 2002 and sold to private developers
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: ALCOA HOUSES AND PUBLIC BUILDINGS
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aluminum Company of America House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story frame house with front and rear gables, interior central chimney, built ca. 1920
Historical -- typical "company house" built by ALCOA for supervisory personnel. Company encouraged their renters to become homeowners.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: ALCOA HOUSES AND PUBLIC BUILDINGS

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: Bethlehem Rd., 0.5 mi. S of Ellejoy Rd., Maryville, TN
Current Use: Opened by Bethlehem Cemetery Association, on request, for weddings, homecomings, etc.

Address: 1004 E. Lamar Alexander Pkwy., Maryville, TN

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: Cades Cove, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, TN

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Current Use: Limited use as office space

Historical -- significant to the Aluminum Company's contribution to defense and war efforts in the 1940s

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Address: 1202 Oak Park Ave., Maryville, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story frame, with hip and gable roof, built in the 1880s

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John F. Shea House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two and one-half story frame house built in 1904 in the Queen Anne style

Historical -- built by Shea for George Townsend who was brother to W. B. Townsend, President of Little River Railroad and Lumber Company; one of the few remaining buildings associated with the company

Current Use: Since 1982, Little River Railroad and Lumber Company Museum

History of transportation -- terminus for both the Knoxville & Augusta RR (later Southern RR) and the Little River RR

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: 502 E. Lamar Alexander Parkway, Maryville, TN
Current Use: Center for Campus Ministry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- built of brick in 1888 in form of Greek cross; handsome oak interior woodwork.
Historical -- built as a memorial to Prof. Thomas Jefferson Lamar, the college's "second founder".

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: Lowes Ferry Rd., l mi. N of Louisville,TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story, three bay residence of limestone construction, features finely crafted jack arching, a date stone (1802) on the lintel above the door, two chimneys, frame ell
Historical -- scene of a murder in the 1840s of a Mr. Humes by a slave Charlie
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: HOUSES AND BARNS IN BLOUNT COUNTY

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story, symmetrical plan, three bay brick Italianate design residence built in 1874 with a one story ell; significant interior woodwork.

Address: Happy Valley Rd., Tallassee, TN

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: Front St. and Big Springs Rd.,, Friendsville, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- unusual Four Room Plan with four connected linear rooms each originally having an outside as well as an inside entrance; built ca.1850
Historical -- John Hackney operated a saw and grist mill on Gallahar's Creek in the 19th century; Pat Stinnett, who owned the house in the early 20th century, operated a local quarry

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: C. L. Babcock House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story frame with hip roof, front dormers, porch, built in ca. 1916-17

Historical -- originally occupied by C. L. Babcock, founder of Babcock Lumber and Land Company. The company built saw and finishing mills, employee housing, a store, clubhouse, and school in the area then called "North Maryville."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: Old Walland Hwy, 0.1 mi. N of Cold Springs Rd. Walland TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Historical -- a mill site since 1842 and location of Peery Brothers Mill after 1905; operating as a tourist attraction in the late 1980s when it burned; only the dam remains
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: SCHOOLS, CHURCHES, MILLS, QUARRY, BRIDGES AND COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS IN BLOUNT CO

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Arthur Kennedy House
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story frame house w/rear ell and gable roof, Greek Revival features in porches, dates from 1850
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: LOUISVILLE HISTORIC DISTRICT; (NR as Louisville Historic District)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pflanze Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Address: Broadway Ave., downtown Maryville, TN
Current Use: Classic movies and live music are presented in the building which is restored to its 1934 look as the Palace Theater.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- two story brick commercial building with Italianate influences, constructed ca. 1868 by Charles Pflanze.
Commercial -- originally a furniture and casket shop, the building later housed a Five and Dime, a movie theater, and a drug store.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: MARYVILLE
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries, Digital Initiatives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nicholson House or "Millennium Manor"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Address: Corner Wright Rd. and Harding St., Alcoa, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural and cultural history -- one story house of pink marble with basement and arched and hip roof. Built by William Andrew Nicholson, by hand, from 1937 to 1946, "to survive Armageddon and enjoy the millennium to follow."
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Location: ALCOA HOUSES AND PUBLIC BUILDINGS
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries, Digital Initiatives

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
Address: Old Walland Hwy, Walland, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Industrial -- one of few significant and unaltered resources related to the operation of Schlosser Leather Company; A. J. "Jack" Fisher, works manager, lived in this one story frame house built ca. 1905

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This structure appears on the National Historical Registry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural -- Colonial Revival style, brick.
